Supply Curve: o The supply curve represents the relationship between the quantity of a good or service that suppliers are willing to produce and sell at various price levels. o Typically, the supply curve slopes upward, indicating that as prices increase, suppliers are willing to produce and offer more of the product. o It reflects the positive correlation between price and quantity supplied. 2. Inverse Supply Curve: o The inverse supply curve is essentially the opposite of the regular supply curve. o Instead of showing the relationship between price and quantity supplied, it shows the relationship between quantity supplied and price. o In other words, it represents the quantity of a good or service that suppliers are willing to produce and sell at different price levels. o The inverse supply curve slopes downward, indicating that as prices increase, suppliers are willing to produce and offer less of the product. o This concept is particularly relevant in electricity markets, where the supply of electricity is influenced by factors such as production costs, availability of resources, and technological constraints. 3. Why “Inverse”?: o The term “inverse” emphasizes the reverse relationship depicted by the curve: as prices rise, the quantity supplied decreases. o It's a way to highlight the negative correlation between price and quantity supplied, which is different from the usual positive correlation seen in regular supply curves.
